text: I'm Cheryl I'm the director of ecosystem
at the cloud native computing foundation
and today I'm going to talk about how
and why the kubernetes community has
grown to its present state what does a
open source foundation like the CN CF
really do and then some of the trends
that we see in 2019 and upcoming
challenges for 2020 so kubernetes is one
of the highest velocity open source
projects ever
so this graph plots the top 30 projects
by different axes so the x-axis is the
number of commits the y-axis is the
number of pull requests and issues and
the size of the bubble represents the
number of authors and Linux is this one
the purple circle at the top right hand
corner and then kubernetes is the pink
circle sort of to the middle at the top
but kubernetes is rare if not unique in
the open source world in that it was
defined very early on as both a project
and the community so let's look at some
statistics around the community
kubernetes is made up of 1.1 million
contributions from 35,000 contributors
and more than 2,000 contributing
companies and we're seeing over time
that these companies are getting more
and more diverse so Google and Red Hat
initially made up 85% of contributions
today they make up about 35% as other
companies get involved the same is true
of the countries that contributors are
in so initially the majority of
contributors came from the United States
and today that none
it's gone down to about 40% as other
people from other countries can get
involved so the CN CF is a neutral home
which hosts kubernetes but actually more
than 40 open source projects in total
and the role of the CN CF is to foster
these open source projects so in
practice CN CF does things that
open-source developers don't want to do
themselves so it runs marketing it runs
events like this the kubernetes forums
we provide continuous integration for
the projects you pay for security audits
we hire technical writers to write
documentation and translators to
translate it and we hold the legal
trademarks for these projects and
something that we do every year is we
run a survey to take a pulse of the
community and what the community is
thinking about now this is a very early
preview because these numbers have not
been published publicly at all so this
is the first time these numbers have
been shown and the survey that we run
this year had 1,100 responses for an
about 65% from software engineers and
sis admins so you're probably not
surprised to know that containers are
pretty mainstream 85% of people reported
that they run containers in production
but deployments large deployments are
getting more and more common 19% of
people said they run more than 5,000
containers
15 percent said they run more than 5,000
machines
that's virtual machines as well as bare
metal and 10 percent even said they run
more than 50 clusters
and the top challenges that people
report facing include the cultural
changes when working with the developer
team security as Liz just talked about
the complexity of the solution and a
lack of training and expertise here are
some of the other challenges that people
have seen logging monitoring and what I
want to say here is that the other
challenges are generally going down over
time so each of the bars here represent
surveys from 2016 2017 2018 and over
time these problems are generally going
down as more resources and tools are
available for people to solve these
challenges we're seeing that some of the
tools are some of the projects within CN
CF and kubernetes Prometheus container d
chord e NS and Envoy are generally going
up increasing compared to 2018 as fluent
eg RPC Jaeger and linker D are roughly
stable compared to 2018 and in a little
bit more detail about how people
actually manage the complexity of large
deployments so 44% are using a service
mesh 70% are auto scaling 50% are using
server less on the other hand cloud
native storage is perhaps a little bit
behind many people are evaluating
storage not so many people have actually
run cloud native storage projects like
work or open EBS in production and one
good side that one good option upshot
that we're seeing is that 55 percent of
people are releasing at least weekly
so daily or
weekly and 80% have reported that
they've automated part or all of their
release process so this is a good sign
that the kind of get ops model is
starting to come into prominence so some
takeaways for you so cloud native
deployments are getting larger and
they're getting more sophisticated the
widest spread challenge is actually the
cultural changes that you need to work
with developer team to ensure they
understand how the cloud native systems
work and then increased release
automation is actually paying off so
more companies are doing smaller more
frequent releases so these slides are on
my blog at a shower comm thank you so
much
[Applause]
